clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Aerobic Training in End Stage Renal Disease Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Aerobic Training During Hemodialysis on Exercise Tolerance in End Stage Renal Disease Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: Federal University of Juiz de Fora

clinical_study.source: Federal University of Juiz de Fora

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators raised the hypothesis that exercise training would be associated with improvement in exercise tolerance and VO2 kinetics in hemodialysis patients.

detailed_description.textblock: End-stage renal disease (ESRD) is associated with several hemodynamic and peripheral muscle abnormalities which could slow the kinetics of O2 uptake(VO2)and diminished tolerance to incremental exercise. Although previous studies have shown that aerobic training is able to accelerate VO2 kinetics in several disease populations, little is known if these positive findings are also applicable to hemodialysis patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Effects of aerobic training during hemodialysis on exercise tolerance and VO2 kinetics in end stage renal disease patients
primary_outcome.description: Before and after the intervention or control periods, the participants were submitted to an incremental work rate test and, two days apart, to a constant work rate test to the limit of tolerance.

arm_group.description: Patients included in the exercise group were submitted to intra-dialytic exercise training, 3 times per week for 12 weeks.
Patients allocated to the control group remained in regular dialysis treatment during the same timeframe.

intervention.description: Patients included in the exercise group were submitted to intra-dialytic exercise training, 3 times per week for 12 weeks.
